title: Mehran Score for Post-PCI Contrast Nephropathy
description: Predicts risk of contrast-induced nephropathy (CIN) after percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). The score uses 8 clinical variables to stratify patients into risk categories and guide preventive strategies.

parameters.name: hypotension
parameters.description: Systolic blood pressure <80 mmHg for ≥1 hour requiring inotropic support or intra-aortic balloon pump within 24 hours of catheterization

parameters.name: congestive_heart_failure
parameters.description: CHF class III/IV by New York Heart Association Classification and/or history of pulmonary edema

parameters.name: anemia
parameters.description: Baseline hematocrit <39% for men and <36% for women

parameters.name: contrast_volume_ml
parameters.description: Total volume of contrast media used (in mL)

result.name: mehran_score
result.description: Total Mehran score for contrast-induced nephropathy risk

ranges.interpretation: 7.5% risk of contrast-induced nephropathy. 0.04% risk of CIN requiring dialysis. Standard preventive measures recommended including adequate hydration.
14.0% risk of contrast-induced nephropathy. 0.12% risk of CIN requiring dialysis. Consider enhanced preventive measures including N-acetylcysteine, sodium bicarbonate, and minimizing contrast volume.

26.1% risk of contrast-induced nephropathy. 1.09% risk of CIN requiring dialysis. Aggressive preventive measures recommended. Consider alternative imaging if possible or minimize contrast volume with careful monitoring.

57.4% risk of contrast-induced nephropathy. 12.6% risk of CIN requiring dialysis. Maximum preventive measures required. Strongly consider alternative imaging modalities if clinically appropriate. If PCI necessary, use minimal contrast with aggressive hydration and renal protection.

references: Mehran R, Aymong ED, Nikolsky E, Lasic Z, Iakovou I, Fahy M, et al. A simple risk score for prediction of contrast-induced nephropathy after percutaneous coronary intervention: development and initial validation. J Am Coll Cardiol. 2004 Oct 6;44(7):1393-9. doi: 10.1016/j.jacc.2004.06.068.

Wi J, Ko YG, Kim JS, Kim BK, Choi D, Ha JW, et al. Impact of contrast-induced acute kidney injury with transient or persistent renal dysfunction on long-term outcomes of patients with acute myocardial infarction undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention. Heart. 2011 Nov;97(21):1753-7. doi: 10.1136/hrt.2010.218677.

Narula A, Mehran R, Weisz G, Dangas GD, Yu J, Généreux P, et al. Contrast-induced acute kidney injury after primary percutaneous coronary intervention: results from the HORIZONS-AMI substudy. Eur Heart J. 2014 Jun 14;35(23):1533-40. doi: 10.1093/eurheartj/ehu063.
formula: Score = Hypotension (5 points) + IABP (5 points) + CHF (5 points) + Age >75 (4 points) + Anemia (3 points) + Diabetes (3 points) + (Contrast volume in mL / 100) + eGFR points (6 if <20, 4 if 20-39, 2 if 40-59, 0 if ≥60)
notes: CIN is defined as an increase ≥0.5 mg/dL (or ≥25%) in serum creatinine at 48 hours post-PCI.
Should not be used in patients with pre-existing end-stage renal disease on dialysis.
Should not be used in patients with contrast exposure within 1 week of the index procedure.
The score has been validated with excellent calibration and discriminatory capacity (C-statistic >0.8).
Consider renal protective measures such as N-acetylcysteine and limiting contrast volume in high-risk patients.
Hypotension criteria requires both SBP <80 mmHg AND need for inotropic support or IABP.
